intro: Dipcadi serotinum, commonly known as the late squill, is a bulbous plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and clusters of white or pale blue flowers. The plant produces a single, elongated bulb that stores nutrients for the next growing season. It typically blooms in late summer to early autumn, making it a distinctive feature in its native habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it has been cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
